name: rail
content:
rail

noun
 
 
/reɪl/
 
/reɪl/
Idioms
jump to other results
  1. ​
     
    [countable] a wooden or metal bar placed around something as a barrier or to provide support
    • She leaned on the ship's rail and gazed out to sea.
    see also guard rail, handrail
    Extra Examples
    • She climbed onto the top fence rail.
    • She held tightly on to the rail.
    • After the accident a guard rail was placed all the way along the cliff path.
    • She came slowly down the stairs, holding the banister rail.
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadjective
    • guard
    • safety
    • curtain
    • …
    verb + rail
    • grab
    • grasp
    • grip
    • …
    preposition
    • on a/​the rail
    • over a/​the rail
    See full entry
  2. ​
     
    [countable] a bar fixed to the wall for hanging things on
    • a picture/curtain/towel rail
    see also picture rail, towel rail
    Extra Examples
    • There was thick dust on the picture rail.
    • Lace curtains hung from the brass rails over the bed.
    • heated towel rails
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadjective
    • guard
    • safety
    • curtain
    • …
    verb + rail
    • grab
    • grasp
    • grip
    • …
    preposition
    • on a/​the rail
    • over a/​the rail
    See full entry
  3. ​
    enlarge image
     
    [countable, usually plural] each of the two metal bars that form the track that trains run on
    • The train thundered along the rails.
    Extra Examples
    • The train came off the rails.
    • Trams run along rails.
    • Weeds grew between the rails.
    • A child was seen crossing the rails.
    • The gun is mounted on rails.
    Topics Transport by bus and trainb2
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryverb + rail
    • run along rails
    • run on rails
    preposition
    • along (the) rails
    • between the rails
    • on (the) rails
    • …
    phrases
    • come off the rails
    • go off the rails
    • ride the rails
    • …
    See full entry
  4. ​
     
    [uncountable] (often before another noun) railways as a means of transport
    • by rail to travel by rail
    • rail travel/services/fares
    • a rail link/network
    Extra Examples
    • He uses a combination of commuter rail and subway to get to work.
    • Many business people now opt for high-speed rail rather than flying.
    • We went from London to Budapest by rail.
    • the Channel Tunnel rail link
    • efforts to modernize the rail network
    Topics Transport by bus and trainb2
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadjective
    • high-speed
    • light
    • commuter
    • …
    rail + noun
    • fare
    • ticket
    • network
    • …
    preposition
    • by rail
    See full entry
    5. Word Originnoun Middle English: from Old French reille ‘iron rod’, from Latin regula ‘straight stick, rule’.
see also dado rail
Idioms
get back on the rails
  1. ​(informal) to become successful again after a period of failure, or to begin functioning normally again
    • He has helped get the company back on the rails again.
    Topics Successc2
go off the rails (informal)
  1. ​to start behaving in a way that is strange or unacceptable, for example drinking a lot or taking drugs
    • She went completely off the rails after her sister died.
    • She was worried her son was going to go completely off the rails.
  2. ​to lose control and stop functioning correctly
    • The company has gone badly off the rails in recent years.
    Topics Difficulty and failurec2
jump the rails
  1. ​(of a train) to leave the track suddenly
See rail in the Oxford Advanced American DictionarySee rail in the Oxford Learner's Dictionary of Academic English

name: rail

rail

verb
 
/reɪl/
 
/reɪl/
 [intransitive, transitive] (formal)
Verb Forms
present simple I / you / we / they rail
 
/reɪl/
 
/reɪl/
he / she / it rails
 
/reɪlz/
 
/reɪlz/
past simple railed
 
/reɪld/
 
/reɪld/
past participle railed
 
/reɪld/
 
/reɪld/
-ing form railing
 
/ˈreɪlɪŋ/
 
/ˈreɪlɪŋ/
Phrasal Verbs
jump to other results
  1. ​rail (at/against something/somebody) | + speech (formal) to complain about something/somebody in a very angry way synonym rage
    • She railed against the injustice of it all.
    Topics Feelingsc2
    Word Originverb late Middle English: from French railler, from Provençal ralhar ‘to jest’, based on an alteration of Latin rugire ‘to bellow’.
Phrasal Verbs
  • rail in
  • rail off

name: rail in
content:
rail in

phrasal verb
jump to other results
rail something in/off
  1. ​to separate an area or object from others by placing rails around it
    • The machine was railed off as a safety precaution.
See rail in in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary

rail off

phrasal verb
jump to other results
rail something in/off
  1. ​to separate an area or object from others by placing rails around it
    • The machine was railed off as a safety precaution.

name: dado rail
content:
dado rail

noun
 
/ˈdeɪdəʊ reɪl/
 
/ˈdeɪdəʊ reɪl/
jump to other results
  1. ​a raised line around the wall of a room, that separates the dado from the upper part of the wall
Check pronunciation: dado rail

name: guard rail
content:
guard rail

noun
 
/ˈɡɑːd reɪl/
 
/ˈɡɑːrd reɪl/
jump to other results
  1. ​a bar placed on the edge of a path, a boat, etc. to protect people and prevent them falling over the edgeTopics Transport by waterc2
  2. ​(North American English)
    (British English crash barrier)
    a strong low fence or wall at the side of a road or between the two halves of a major road such as a motorway or interstateTopics Transport by car or lorryc2
See guard rail in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: guard rail

name: British Rail
content:
British Rail

 
/ˌbrɪtɪʃ ˈreɪl/
 
/ˌbrɪtɪʃ ˈreɪl/
jump to other results
  1. ​the company, owned by the state, which ran the rail transport system in Britain until the 1990s, when it was separated into several smaller companies and sold to private owners see also Network Rail
Check pronunciation: British Rail

name: Network Rail
content:
Network Rail

 
/ˌnetwɜːk ˈreɪl/
 
/ˌnetwɜːrk ˈreɪl/
jump to other results
  1. ​the company that owns and is responsible for looking after and repairing all the tracks, bridges, signals, etc. on the railways in Britain. It also owns most railway stations and directly manages some of the biggest of them. Train services are run by a number of different companies.
Check pronunciation: Network Rail
